section.title: Overview
section.para: There are several instances when you will need to code in the CeltiXfire documentation. You may need to use a class name, interface name, or element name as part of a sentence. You will also need to provide long code samples in many places. Docbook has a number of elements that are used for placing code in your documentation.

note.para: XML mark-up, such as WSDL and XMLSchema, are also considered code for the purposes of CeltiXfire documentation.

section.title: Examples
section.para: When providing code examples, you need to seperate them from the text and provide a caption for them. To do this you use the example element. You should always provide a descriptive value for the example element's id attribute.

As shown in , the first child of the example element is a title element. The contents of the title element will be used as the caption of the example. It will also be used as the text for any cross references.

note.para: If you want to have different text appear when cross referencing an example, set the example element's xreflabel attribute.

section.para: The last child of the example element is the programlisting element. The programlisting element contains the code sample itself. Any text placed inside the programlisting element is treated literally. Therefore, any spacing that you use will be exactly reproduced when the document is produced.

warning.para: When using XML inside a programlisting element you must not use the < or >characters. Instead use < and >.

example.title: Example Mark-Up
example.programlisting:
<example id="example_example">
  <title>Example Mark-Up</title>
  <programlisting>public class ServiceName extends javax.xml.ws.Service
{
  ...
  public ServiceName(URL wsdlLocation, QName serviceName) { }
  
  public ServiceName() { }

  public Greeter getPortName() { }
  .
  .
  .
}

section.title: Code Blocks
section.para: There are cases when you need to use a block of code, but do not need to create a formal example with a title. In such cases you can use one of two methods:

In terms of the generated output, there is no difference between the two approaches. The real difference is in the complexity of the mark-up and the formality of the structure you wish to use. In the CeltiXfire documentation, the prefered method is to simply use the programlisting element. However, if you feel that a code block needs to be wrapped in an informalexample element, that is fine.

section.title: In-line Code
section.para: There are many instances where you need to place a code artifact in a block of text such as when you are refering to a Java class or an XML element. Docbook has a number of specialized elements for placing code artifacts in-line. The ones used in CeltiXfire include:

section.title: XML Artifacts
section.para: When placing XML artifacts such as element names or attribute names in your text wrap them in an sgmltag element. To specify the type of XML artifact, the sgmltag element's class attribute is always used. shows the values used for the class attribute.

row.entry: Specifies that the artifact is an attribute of an XML element.
Specifies that the artifact is an XML element.
Specifies that the artifact is the value of an XML element's attribute.
Specifies an XML element that does not hold any data such as foo.
